title: George Alexander Forsyth
text:
George Alexander Forsyth (November 7, 1837, – September 12, 1915) was a United States military officer most notable for his service in the <a href="cavalry">cavalry</a>.
Early life.
Forsyth was born in <a href="Muncy%2C%20Pennsylvania">Muncy, Pennsylvania</a>. He attended <a href="Canandaigua%20Academy">Canandaigua Academy</a> and moved to Illinois before the <a href="American%20Civil%20War">American Civil War</a>.
Civil War.
Forsyth enlisted April 19, 1861, as a <a href="private%20%28rank%29">private</a> in Barker's Company, Chicago Volunteer Dragoons (a 3-month regiment) and mustered out August 18, 1861.
He received a commission as a <a href="First%20Lieutenant%23United%20States">first lieutenant</a> in the <a href="8th%20Regiment%20Illinois%20Volunteer%20Cavalry">8th Illinois Cavalry</a> on September 18, 1861, followed by promotions to <a href="Captain%20%28United%20States%29">captain</a> on February 12, 1862, and <a href="Major%20%28United%20States%29">major</a> on September 1, 1863. He saw action in all major campaigns fought by the <a href="Army%20of%20the%20Potomac">Army of the Potomac</a>. He also fought in many cavalry actions in the <a href="Valley%20Campaigns%20of%201864">Shenandoah Valley</a>, where he served as <a href="aide-de-camp">aide-de-camp</a> to <a href="Major%20general%20%28United%20States%29">Maj. Gen.</a> <a href="Philip%20Sheridan">Philip Sheridan</a> and received a <a href="Brevet%20%28military%29">brevet</a> promotion to <a href="Colonel%20%28United%20States%29">colonel</a> on October 19, 1864, for his service at <a href="Battle%20of%20Opequon">Third Winchester</a> and <a href="Battle%20of%20Cedar%20Creek">Cedar Creek</a>. He was appointed a brevet <a href="Brigadier%20general%20%28United%20States%29">brigadier general</a> of volunteers on March 13, 1865, part of widespread ceremonial promotion of officers at the end of the war.
After the Civil War ended, he received a commission in the <a href="Regular%20Army%20%28United%20States%29">regular army</a> as a major in the <a href="9th%20Cavalry%20Regiment%20%28United%20States%29">9th U.S. Cavalry</a> on July 28, 1866, with brevets on March 2, 1867, to <a href="Lieutenant%20colonel%20%28United%20States%29">lieutenant colonel</a> for gallantry during the Civil War at the <a href="Battle%20of%20Dinwiddie%20Court%20House">Battle of Dinwiddie Court House</a> and to colonel for the <a href="Battle%20of%20Five%20Forks">Battle of Five Forks</a>.
Postbellum career.
In 1868 Forsyth raised a band of fifty frontiersmen to serve as scouts into <a href="Indian%20Territory">Indian Territory</a>. He led this group to victory at the <a href="Battle%20of%20Beecher%20Island">Battle of Beecher Island</a> against <a href="Roman%20Nose">Roman Nose</a>. For this action, he received a brevet promotion to brigadier general effective September 18, 1868. Between 1869 and 1873 he served as military secretary to <a href="Lieutenant%20general%20%28United%20States%29">Lt. Gen.</a> Sheridan, and between 1878 and 1881 as Sheridan's <a href="aide-de-camp">aide-de-camp</a>. In his permanent rank, he received a promotion to lieutenant colonel of the <a href="4th%20Cavalry%20Regiment%20%28United%20States%29">4th U.S. Cavalry</a> on June 26, 1881.
On April 23, 1885, at <a href="Fort%20Bowie">Fort Bowie</a>, <a href="Arizona">Arizona</a>, he married Natalie Sedgewick Beaumont, the twenty-two-year-old daughter of fellow 4th Cavalry officer <a href="Eugene%20B.%20Beaumont">Eugene B. Beaumont</a>.
Forsyth retired from the Army in March 1890 and was promoted to colonel on the Retired List in April 1904. He died at <a href="Rockport%2C%20Massachusetts">Rockport</a>, <a href="Massachusetts">Massachusetts</a>, and was buried in <a href="Arlington%20National%20Cemetery">Arlington National Cemetery</a>. He was the author of the 1900 work "Thrilling Days in Army Life".
